sen.j: 初期荘園（しょきしょうえん）は、8～9世紀に未墾地の墾田化・既墾の墾田の集積を通して成立した荘園。
sen.e: Shoki shoen (early shoen) was a shoen (manor) which was established through reclaimation of wasteland and collection of reclaimed field in the eighth to nineth century.
Shoki shoen (early shoen) were shoen (manors) established through an accumulation of wasteland and a collection of reclaimed rice fields from the eighth to the ninth century.
sen.cmt: "reclaimation" is not a word, as far as I can tell, so I changed it to "accumulation" for "集積"; added "rice"; fixed grammar
sen.e: Shoki shoen (early shoen) were shoen (manors) established through an accumulation of wasteland and a collection of reclaimed rice fields from the eighth to the ninth century.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 墾田地系荘園（こんでんちけいしょうえん）とも言う。
sen.e: It was also called kondenchi ke shoen (manors established by reclaiming fields).
They were also called Kondenchi Ke Shoen (manors established by the reclaiming of fields).
sen.cmt: capitalzed "Kondenchi Ke Shoen"; fixed grammar
sen.e: They were also called Kondenchi Kei Shoen (manors established by the reclaiming of fields).
sen.cmt: Ke→ Kei

sen.j: 租を納めねばならず、律令支配体制から脱却していない。
sen.e: A land tax should be paid for it, indicating it was still under the Ritsuryo system.
Land taxes applied to the reclaimed fields, indicating that they were still under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).
sen.cmt: added description for Ritsuryo system; fixed grammar
sen.e: Land taxes applied to the reclaimed fields, indicating that they were still under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 墾田永年私財法が制定されると中央の寺社・貴族は、律令国家・国衙の積極的な援助のもとに大規模な開墾を展開する。
sen.e: After the Konden einen shizai Law (a law which allowed farmers who reclaimed a field to own it permanently) was enacted, temples and shrines, as well as nobles in the capital started to reclaim a field on a large scale with an active support of kokuga (provincial government offices) of the Japanese nation under the ritsuryo codes.

After the Konden Einen Shizai Law (a law allowing farmers to permanently own reclaimed fields) was enacted, temples and shrines, as well as nobles in the capital began reclaiming fields on a large scale with active support from the Kokuga (provincial government offices) under the ritsuryo code.
sen.cmt: capitalized "Konden Shizai"; eliminated "of the Japanese nation" since it was awkward and felt unecessary; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: After the Konden Einen Shizai Law (a law allowing farmers to permanently own reclaimed fields) was enacted, temples and shrines, as well as nobles in the capital began reclaiming fields on a large scale with active support from the Kokuga (provincial government offices) under the ritsuryo code.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 墾田の要所には開発と経営のため、「荘」または「荘所」という家屋が設置された。
sen.e: At important points of the reclaimed field, houses called "sho" or "shosho" were constructed for the development and management of the land.
At important points in the reclaimed fields, houses called "sho" or "shosho" were constructed for the development and management of the land.
sen.cmt: changed "of" to "in" before "the reclaimed fields"
sen.e: At important points in the reclaimed fields, houses called "sho" or "shosho" were constructed for the development and management of the land.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 荘と墾田の結合体を「荘田」または「荘園」と呼ぶようになった。
sen.e: The combination of the sho and the reclaimed field came to be called "Shoden" (field within a manor) or "shoen".
The combination of the sho and the reclaimed field came to be called "Shoden" (field within a manor) or "shoen."
sen.cmt: fixed period placement
sen.e: The combination of the sho and the reclaimed field came to be called "Shoden" (field within a manor) or "shoen."
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 律令国家・国衙の援助で広大な未開地を設定して開発する、自墾地系荘園（じこんちけいしょうえん）は地方に多く、すでに熟田化した墾田を買得・相博・譲与・寄進などで集積した、既墾地系荘園（きこんちけいしょうえん）は畿内に多い。
sen.e: In the country there existed many jikonchi ke shoen, in which a vast wasteland was defined to develop with the aid of the kokuga of the Japanese nation under the ritsuryo codes, while in the Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara) there existed many kikonchi ke shoen, which was collected through purchase, exchange, transfer, and donation of konata, a well-cultivated rice field.

There were many Jikonchi Ke Shoen in rural areas, in which vast wastelands were defined in order to develop the land with the aid of the Kokuga under the ritsuryo code. In the Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara), there were many Kikonchi Ke Shoen, which were collected through purchase, exchange, transfer, and donation of well-cultivated rice fields called Konata.
sen.cmt: capitalized "Jikonchi Ke Shoen," "Kikonchi Ke Shoen," and "Konata"; split sentence into two; fixed grammar
sen.e: There were many Jikonchi Kei Shoen in rural areas, in which vast wastelands were defined in order to develop the land with the aid of the Kokuga under the ritsuryo code, while, in the Kinai region (provinces surrounding Kyoto and Nara), there were many Kikonchi Ke Shoen, which were collected through purchase, exchange, transfer, and donation of well-cultivated rice fields called Konata.
sen.cmt: Ke→ Kei, 一文にしました。

sen.j: これらの初期荘園には荘民が存在せず、耕作労働力は周辺の班田農民に対する賃租が一般的であった。
sen.e: In those shoki shoen there lived no people, therefore generally farmers living in the neibouring handen (the allotted farmland) worked there as chinso (land taxes under the Ritsuryo system).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In general, nobody lived in the Shoki Shoen, so farmers from neighboring handen (alloted farmlands) worked the fields by renting them under the Ritsuryo system.
sen.cmt: found definition for "賃租" at: <http://dictionary.goo.ne.jp/leaf/jn/128329/m1u/%E8%B3%83%E7%A7%9F/>; eliminated "chinso" since there is no wikipedia article for it; fixed grammar
sen.e: In general, nobody lived in the Shoki Shoen, so farmers from neighboring handen (allotted farmlands) worked the fields by renting them under the Ritsuryo system.
sen.cmt: alloted→allotted

sen.j: その支配・経営は国家権力に強く依存していた。
sen.e: The governance and management of the shoki shoen were strongly dependent on the national authority.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The governance and management of Shoki Shoen was strongly dependent on the national authority.

sen.e: The governance and management of Shoki Shoen was strongly dependent on the national authority.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 律令制が解体を始める9世紀には、自墾地系荘園は労働力を確保できなくなり急速に姿を消した。
sen.e: In the ninth century when the ritsuryo system began to dissolve, the jikonchi ke shoen was no longer able to keep its labor power and disappeared quickly.
In the ninth century when the Ritsuryo system began to dissolve, the Jikonchi Ke Shoen were no longer able sustain a work force and quickly disappeared.
sen.cmt: capitalized "Ritsuryo" and "Jikonchi Ke Shoen"; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: In the ninth century when the Ritsuryo system began to dissolve, the Jikonchi Kei Shoen were no longer able sustain a work force and quickly disappeared.
sen.cmt: Ke→ Kei

sen.j: 有力寺社・貴族は労働力の確保のため、在地の新興富豪層を荘長に任じ、負債のため流亡した貧しい人や課役の追及を逃れた人を荘園に迎え入れることで、経営の安定化を図ろうとした。
sen.e: Powerful temples and shrines, as well as nobles tried to stabilize the management by appointing a resident of emerging wealthy class as a sho cho (administrator of a monor) and by accepting poor people who had run off due to a debt or escaped from distribution of assignments in order to keep their labor power.

Nobles, powerful temples and shrines attempted to stabilize the management of the shoen by appointing a resident of an emerging wealthy class as a sho cho (administrator of a manor) and maintaining a labor force by accepting impoverished people who had run off due debts or escaped from their distributed assignments.
sen.cmt: monor→manor; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Nobles, powerful temples and shrines attempted to stabilize the management of the shoen by appointing a resident of an emerging wealthy class as a sho cho (administrator of a manor) and maintaining a labor force by accepting impoverished people who had run off due debts or escaped from their distributed assignments.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 富豪農民の寄進による既墾地系荘園の増加は、律令体制の財政基盤に深刻な動揺を与えた。
sen.e: The expansion of kikonchi ke shoen due to donation from wealthy farmers created serious commotion on the financial base of the Ritsuryo system.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The expansion of Kikonchi Ke Shoen due to donations from wealthy farmers created serious commotion on the financial base of the Ritsuryo system.

sen.e: The expansion of Kikonchi Kei Shoen due to donations from wealthy farmers created serious commotion on the financial base of the Ritsuryo system.

sen.j: 藤原時平は延喜2年（902年）に荘園整理令を発するが効果はなく、班田制は機能不全に陥った。
sen.e: In 902 FUJIWARA no Tokihira put Manor Regulation Acts into effect without success, resulting in the dysfunctional handen-sei (Ritsuryo land-allotment system).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.e: In 902, FUJIWARA no Tokihira put into effect the Manor Regulation Acts without success, resulting in a dysfunctional handen-sei (Ritsuryo land-allotment system).
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: ただし、この時期の荘園は墾田に対する浮浪・班田農民の寄作を基礎としていて、労働奴隷制的でも、領域と住民を一元的に掌握していたわけでもなかった。
sen.e: However, the shoen at that time depended on the labor contribution from vagrants and handen farmers for reclaimed field, and even if it took slave-labor system the field and residents were not controlled in an integrated manner.

The shoen at the time, however, depended on the contribution of labor from vagrants and handen farmers for the reclaimed fields, and even if a slave-labor system was used, the field and residents were not controlled in an integrated manner.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: The shoen at the time, however, depended on the contribution of labor from vagrants and handen farmers for the reclaimed fields, and it is neither slave-labor system, nor the system under which the field and residents were controlled in an integrated manner.
sen.cmt: 文意に合うように書き換えました。

sen.j: また、11～12世紀の寄進型荘園のように、田地の不輸や寄作者の雑役免といった国家的諸権限の割譲もなかった。
sen.e: Cession of the state power, such as fuyu (tax exemption) or zoyakumen (exception from all levies except the regular land tax) for the contributor was not conducted like donated-type of shoen (manors based on donation) of the eleventh to twelfth century.

Furthermore, from the eleventh to twelfth century, cessation of state power, such as fuyu (tax exemptions) and zoyakumen (exception from all levies except regular land taxes) for contributors was not conducted on donated shoen (manors based on donation).
sen.cmt: added "Furthmore"; rearranged sentence and fixed grammar to read more smoothly

sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 領域と住民の全面的掌握を指向する寄進型荘園が、平安時代後期に全国的に成立すると、初期荘園もその中に組み込まれて解消していった。
sen.e: Once the donated-type of shoen which directed to the total control of fields and residents was established nationwide in late Heian period, the syoki syoen was incorporated into that system and eventually disappeared.

As donated shoen, which were oriented towards total control of the fields and residents, were established nationwide in the late Heian period, Shoki Shoen were incorporated into the system and eventually disappeared.
